title: 112_s760
content: The Act may be cited as the "Chesapeake Bay Accountability and Recovery Act of 2011". Definitions are provided in the Act. The Act defines "adaptive management" as a science-based process that evaluates strategies and incorporates new knowledge into programs. The term "Administrator" refers to the head of the Environmental Protection Agency. The term "Chesapeake Bay State" includes Maryland, West Virginia, Delaware, New York, Virginia, Pennsylvania, and the District of Columbia. The "Chesapeake Bay watershed" encompasses the bay and surrounding areas in the mentioned states. The "Chesapeake Executive Council" is defined in a specific act, and "chief executive" refers to the head of an organization. The term "chief executive" refers to the Governor of each State or Commonwealth, the Mayor of the District of Columbia, and the term "Director" means the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. "Restoration activity" includes Federal or State programs that protect, conserve, or restore resources in the Chesapeake Bay watershed. The term "restoration activity" in the Chesapeake Bay watershed includes physical restoration, planning, feasibility studies, scientific research, monitoring, education, and infrastructure development. SEC. 3. CHESAPEAKE BAY CROSSCUT BUDGET. The Director, in consultation with relevant parties, submits an annual financial report to Congress with an interagency crosscut budget displaying proposed funding for Federal and State restoration activities for the upcoming fiscal year, as well as expenditures from the previous three fiscal years. The annual financial report to Congress includes a detailed accounting of all amounts received and obligated by Federal agencies and States for restoration activities in the current and preceding fiscal years. The annual financial report to Congress provides a detailed description of proposed Federal and State restoration activities for the succeeding fiscal year, including project details, status, authorities, funding levels, timelines, risks, adaptive management, and coordinating entities. The Director must report on restoration activities with funding amounts over $100,000 for Federal projects and over $50,000 for State projects. The report must be submitted to the Committees on Appropriations and Natural Resources within 30 days of the President's annual budget submission to Congress. The House and Senate committees responsible for appropriations, natural resources, energy, commerce, and transportation will implement this section starting from the first fiscal year after the enactment of the Act when the President submits a budget to Congress. SEC. 4. ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT PLAN. The Administrator must develop an adaptive management plan for restoration activities in the Chesapeake Bay watershed within 1 year of this Act's enactment. The plan includes specific objectives for improving water quality, habitat, and fisheries, stakeholder participation, monitoring, and modification processes for restoration activities. The Administrator must update the adaptive management plan every 3 years and submit a report to Congress within 60 days after each fiscal year, detailing the implementation of the plan and changes made through adaptive management. This requirement applies to the first fiscal year after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. INDEPENDENT EVALUATOR FOR THE CHESAPEAKE BAY PROGRAM. An Independent Evaluator is appointed by the Administrator to review and report on restoration activities in the Chesapeake Bay watershed, including the use of adaptive management. The evaluator submits a report to Congress every 3 years with findings and recommendations.
